subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] kerning
msgSnippet: A quick update on the font: Paige is testing in with me on her PC, and having some troubles (though I think that is the text file I sent, not the font itself).
messageBody:
A quick update on the font: Paige is testing in with me on her PC,
and having some troubles (though I think that is the text file I
sent, not the font itself). I also noticed that the kerning doesn't
work on my copy of Windows 2000, so I am going to try saving it as an
OpenType font rather than Truetype... not sure whether that is
supported, though. Still needs some testing.

The PDF is in two columns mainly because it looked pretty bad as a
single column: lots of very short paragraphs. Perhaps I can just
change the page size, though, since I think it will mostly be read
online, not printed out (and if printed people can print it two-up).

'recovering' from a friend's birthday party, but I am still working
on these things albeit slowly.

oliver

On Wednesday 2006.07.12, at 14:58, amd64_hacker wrote:
> The font looks really good - I'm eagerly awaiting 'prime-time' :).
>
> Perhaps we should try and work out the rules for glyph substitution
> as a
> group?
> There are other subs which would be nice to have such as the alternate
> forms of #36 and #23.
> If we work out the rules now we could reuse them in other fonts later
> and save sometime.
>
> The PDF looks as good as the font and it is so nice to be able to
> search.
> The only thing I'd mention is that the multi column layout interferes
> with the selection.
> i.e. if I select the last two lines on the last page I get:
>
> Further development is entirely optional —
> though valuable in writing.
> (Notice that it is easier to write the three letters for
> Dr than two.)
>
> I'm guessing this is something to do with how pages 'prints' it and it
> can't be changed?
>
> I can't get over how nice the font and the PDF are on the eyes :)
>
> oliver langan wrote:
>>
>> When the penis enlargement ads start coming in Shavian and
>> Quickscript, we're really in trouble.
>>
>> Speaking of which, I spent some time yesterday playing with a font
>> editor (I think I have mentioned it before: http://
>> fontforge.sourceforge.net/ ) and managed to figure out how to do
>> character pair kerning. This has been a huge problem with QS fonts,
>> for me at least, since spacing between He and short letters (for
>> example) would look as though a space was inserted.
>>
>> So, I spent some time -- a lot of time actually -- converting the
>> 'kingsley' font to a) use the conscript unicode block, b) have a
>> slightly large space, and c) have much better kerning between the
>> letter pairs. The results are really nice, I think:
>>
>> (attempting to paste an image)
>>
>>
>> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
>> ---
>>
>>
>> (smaller version)
>>
>>
>> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
>> ---
>>
>>
>> Note the improved kerning in 'you' and 'rather' in the first
>> sentence.
>> Do you think I went overboard with 'culture' in the last sentence?
>>
>> Using this method, it may be possible to make an almost-senior
>> version
>> of the same font. In fact, if I can figure out the 'alternate glyphs'
>> thing then I might be able to shoehorn half characters in as well.
>>
>> You may notice that the above text is from the QS manual. My reason
>> for doing this, in fact, is because I am attempting to convert the QS
>> manual so that it might be displayed on the web, using (downloadable)
>> unicode fonts. The Kingsley font (and jerome too) is a close match
>> for
>> the writing in the manual, but when used to write more than a single
>> word it just looked bad: now it looks much better, and with
>> Unicode it
>> is very easy to intermix quickscript and orthodox. I will try
>> uploading an in-progress PDF later today, if I am able to verify that
>> it displays correctly on a machine without the font installed (the
>> font is not ready for prime time, and I'd rather sit on it than have
>> lots of different versions out there).
>>
>> oliver
